ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: For this activity, you will need an actual mitten or a mitten drawn on paper, and a few Two-Color Counters for each child.
When we read The Mitten, we talked about the number of animals who squeezed into the boy’s mitten.

In this activity, you will pretend these counters are cold animals. You can put an animal in or take one out using the counters. We will say how many animals are in the mitten after one joins or leaves.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Place the mitten on the table and one Two-Color Counter in the center. There is one animal in the mitten.

Add Ask a child to add one more animal to the mitten. Guide the child to place a Two-Color Counter on the mitten and tell how many animals there are in all. There was one animal in the mitten. Then, one squirrel crawled in, too. How many animals are in the mitten now?

Remove Ask another child to take away one animal from the mitten, by taking a Two-Color Counter off of the mitten. There were two animals in the mitten. Then one left. How many animals are in the mitten now?

Repeat Continue to ask children to add and remove one animal at a time from the mitten, reaching up to five animals in the mitten through adding. Each time ask, How many animals are in the mitten now?

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Every time we added an animal, the number of animals in the mitten was one higher. When we took an animal away, the number was one lower. Was it easier to count the animals in the mitten when we read the book or in this activity? Why?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Start with only adding animals to the mitten. Use this frame to help children add: How many animals are there now? Let’s count up once from one. One, .
Encourage children to create their own word problems and show them using Two-Color Counters. Challenge children to add and remove more than one animal at a time.

Review key vocabulary, such as animal names and mitten. Use a Magnetic Numeral to show how many animals are in the mitten, placing a new number and pointing to it as you say it each time the amount changes.
Create a mitten on the floor, using tape or a hula hoop. Have children pretend to be the animals, crawling into and out of the mitten.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need about five Connecting Cubes for each child.
Revisit the Vocabulary Let’s review the word communicate. Use the communicate Vocabulary Card to reteach the word.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read The Mitten, we talked about how the animals communicated their needs.

In this activity, I will give each partner a different number of cubes. Then, I will tell you the number of cubes I want both of you to have together. If you do not have that number of cubes, you will have to communicate to me that you need one more or one less.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Pair children into partners. Give Partner As four Connecting Cubes, and Partner Bs three Connecting Cubes.

Ask Once all children have Connecting Cubes, say: I would like everyone to have four Connecting Cubes. How many cubes do you have? Have partners work together to count each set of cubes. Then, encourage Partner Bs to communicate to you that they need one more.

Repeat Do the activity again, this time taking away one cube: Now I would like everyone to have three Connecting Cubes. Encourage both partners to raise their hands and express that they need one less cube. Continue the activity as time allows, each time asking for one more or one fewer cube.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: How were you able to figure out how many cubes you needed to add or take away? How did you communicate with your partner? Why is it important to communicate our needs politely?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Have both partners start with one cube each. First, say you would like everyone to have two cubes. Continue the activity with only addition, moving to subtraction as children are ready.
Challenge children by asking for a number of cubes that is two more or less than the amount of cubes each partner has.

Hold up number cards with numerals to show the number of cubes you would like each partner to have. Share with Spanish-speaking children that communicate has a cognate in Spanish (comunicar). Also, discuss polite ways that children communicate with their families.

Give partners Connecting Cubes of a single color. Children who have difficulty processing colors may find it easier to count objects that have the same properties. You may also provide gloves for children who find it difficult to handle the connecting cubes with their bare fingers.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need sticky notes and markers to graph, as well as children’s own mittens and gloves. If gloves or mittens are not needed because of the weather, prepare some mitten and glove drawings on index cards.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read The Mitten, we sorted the animals into groups and graphed them.
Let’s review the words total, graph, and mitten.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Use the total, graph, and mitten Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words. Explain that a glove is different from a mitten: A glove has space for each one of your fingers. A mitten only has two spaces for fingers.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, you will bring one mitten or glove, whichever you wore to school today, to the table. We will sort them into two groups: mittens and gloves. Then, we will graph how many we have of each.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Sort Have children place their mittens or gloves in the center of the table. Guide children to sort them into mittens or gloves.

Graph Give each child a sticky note and have children write their names. Then, designate two columns to graph the sticky notes: mittens and gloves. Ask children to place their sticky note in the column that represents what they wore on their hands to school today.
Count Ask children to count the number of mittens and number of gloves in each column. Ask, Which total is bigger?

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: We’ve made a bar graph! Did more people wear gloves today, or mittens? How can you tell?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model determining which pile to place your own mitten or glove in. For example: I wore these today. There are five spaces for each of my five fingers, so I know these are gloves. Write your name on a sticky note and model placing it on the table to begin to create the graph.

Have children sort all of the mittens and gloves in various other ways (by size, by whether they are patterned or a solid color, etc.). Guide children to move their sticky notes to create a new bar graph.

Hold up an example of a glove and a mitten as you say each word. Have children point to the one that matches their own. When asking which total is bigger: the gloves or mittens, repeat using synonyms multilingual learners may be more familiar with: Which amount is more? Which one is larger?

Have one child gather and sort mittens and gloves which other children decorate their sticky notes. Repeat your directions as children gather their mittens and gloves to help them stay on task: I can’t wait to see what you wore on your hands to school today!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Revisit the Vocabulary Let’s review the words snowy and windy. Use the snowy and windy Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read What’s the Weather?, we talked about four kinds of weather: rainy, snowy, windy, and sunny.
In this activity, I will show you pictures that show one of the four types of weather we learned about today. You will sort the cards by the kind of weather they show. Then we will graph them.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show children the first Activity Card. Ask, What kind of weather is this? Guide children to respond using one of the four types of weather from the Big Chart of Big Ideas: rainy, snowy, windy, or sunny.
Extend Encourage children to tell you how they know what type of weather is on the card, using details learned from the Big Chart.
Repeat Continue the activity using the other Activity Cards, until all have been sorted into four piles.

Graph Once all cards have been sorted, help children lay them out on the table in the form of a bar graph. Point to each bar, and guide children to count the number of cards in each column. How many cards show sunny weather? How many cards show windy weather?

Talk About Results Talk with children about the results of the graph they made. Which type of weather appears the most? Which type of weather appears the least? How can you tell by looking at the graph?

Start sorting only two types of weather: rainy and sunny. Model sorting a card of each type: This card shows water falling from the sky! I know that this is rainy weather. This card has a bright sun, and nothing is getting wet. It must be sunny weather!
After all cards have been graphed, encourage children to sort the cards in other ways: a picture containing or not containing a person; cold or warm weather; etc.
Review key vocabulary, such as sunny, rainy, weather, sort, and graph. Encourage children to show the number of cards in each bar by holding up that number of fingers.
As children sort the cards, encourage them to act out each type of weather. They may pretend to shiver for snowy, fly a kite for windy, bathe in the sun for sunny, and open an umbrella for rainy.
